runs.text: Read the title, and have students repeat as they point to each word.
Ask students to look at the picture and tell what they think the girl in the background is doing.
routine. You will prompt students to use this word to talk about the story.
are a person, animal, or objects characteristics or features.
The puppy has many of the same
do you admire, or really like, in a person?
Have students whisper-read the story. Circulate, listen in, and offer corrective feedback.
When completed, ask the following questions to check comprehension. Prompt students to answer each question with a partner before you call on volunteers to answer the question.
Find the word that tells whose mom was in the yard planting. (Bellas)
What did Matteo put on the doll? Find the sentence that answers the question.
What are some traits Bellas family thinks she has?
What is something you searched for and found? How did you find it?
Have students reread the book during independent work time and as a warm-up to the next days lesson.
Read the title, and have students repeat as they point to each word.
Explain that this cartoon is about a system of measurement. Discuss what it means to measure something.
routine. You will prompt students to use this term to talk about the story.
of fruit to make the pie.
of ingredients do you need to make your favorite dish?
Have students whisper-read the text. Circulate, listen in, and offer corrective feedback.
When completed, ask the following questions to check comprehension. Prompt students to answer each question with a partner before you call on volunteers to answer the question.
Whose fantastic meter stick is it? (Mason Metrics)
What units are used to measure length in the metric system? Find the sentence that answers the question.
that people measure? Why do people need to measure them?
Why do you think the metric system is difficult for some Americans?
Have students reread the book during independent work time and as a warm-up to the next days lesson.
Have students whisperread each sentence. Then ask them to chorally read it.
. Have them point to and read those words to a partner.
Have students write a sentence using the word
. Have students read the sentence to a partner.
Remind students that they can chunk sentences into meaningful parts when reading them aloud.  Model reading the first two sentences by chunking the subject and predicate parts:
My sisters doll/is made of paper. The twins birthday/is on Sunday.
Have partners practice chunking for the remaining sentences.
Read the title. Explain that this text asks questions that are riddles. Each riddle contains clues about the answer, which is always about a game.

For the first reading, you read the riddles and have students read the answer. Then switch roles and repeat for the second reading. Partners can switch roles during the rereadings: one reads the riddle and the other reads the answer.
Prompt students to find and circle the noun in the riddle with
. Then have students chorally read the circled word. Ask students questions about the text to confirm understanding.
Say each word, guide students to write it, then proceed to the next word in the sentence.
Provide supports for words that are completely comprised of the phonics skills students have learned.
These supports include sound boxes, tapping the sounds, and so on.
Provide supports for the high-frequency words students have learned.
When completed, have students read the entire sentence aloud.
Self-Correct: Write the sentences on the board, and have students self-correct. Take note of errors on each students Student Observation Form.
Read the title, and have students repeat as they point to the words.
Have students tell what they know about atoms and elements. Explain that they will learn more about these scientific terms in this text.
routine. You will prompt students to use this word to talk about the text.
that he did poorly on the test because he did not study.
can you make about a friend by thinking about her actions?
Have students whisper-read the text. Circulate, listen in, and offer corrective feedback.
When completed, ask the following questions to check comprehension. Prompt students to answer each question with a partner before you call on volunteers to answer the question.
What objects family is this text about? (the atoms)
What are some examples of elements? Find sentences that answer this question.
can you make about elements based on what you read?
What additional information about elements would you like to learn? Why?
Have students reread the book during independent work time and as a warm-up to the next days lesson.
Have students whisperread each sentence. Then ask them to chorally read it.
. Have them point to and read those words to a partner.
Have students write a sentence using the word
. Have them read the sentence to a partner.

Identify and discuss different types of sentences by looking at end punctuation. Help students identify statements (sentences 3, 4, 6, 7), questions (sentences 1, 2, 5, 8, 10) and exclamations (sentence 9). Model and have students repeat reading each type of sentence with the appropriate expression.
Read the title, and have students repeat as they point to each word. Explain that this is a science text that gives information about what an atom is made up of.

Explain that authors often include diagrams and labeled illustrations to present technical information that may otherwise be difficult to understand. This text includes diagrams to show and compare the different parts of an oxygen and hydrogen atom.
Guide students through a reading of the selection, including the diagrams.
Prompt students to share what they notice and wonder when viewing the diagrams.

Read the title, and have students repeat as they point to each word. This is an on-level selection. It is provided to gauge where students are in their reading progress toward grade-level goals. Students might need to listen and follow along with the e-book for support before they read the book on their own.
Explain to students that they will read a story about a problem with freezing lemonade.
routine. You will prompt students to use this word to talk about the story.

Have students whisperread the story. Circulate, listen in, and offer corrective feedback.
When completed, ask the following questions to check comprehension. Prompt students to answer each question with a partner before you call on volunteers to answer the question.
Whose dad will be home tomorrow? (Essas)
Why does Essa want her dad to have something really special? Find the sentence that answers the question.
What happens to a frozen ice pop if it
What are some things you would put in a freezer? Why?
Have students reread the book during independent work time and as a warm-up to the next days lesson.
Read the title, and have students repeat as they point to each word.
Explain that this text is a brochure advertising hot-air balloon rides. Ask students to predict what kind of information they think will be included in the brochure.

from one store to another? Why or why not?
Have students whisperread the story. Circulate, listen in, and offer corrective feedback.
When completed, ask the following questions to check comprehension. Prompt students to answer each question with a partner before you call on volunteers to answer the question.
Which sunny shores do the hot-air balloons ride over? (Lake Quills)
How does the amount of hot air that goes into the balloon
Find the sentence that answers the question.
Do you think the material used for a hot-air balloon contributes to its safety? Why or why not?
Would you like to take a ride in a hot-air balloon? Why or why not?
Have students reread the book during independent work time and as a warm-up to the next days lesson.
